awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  Bulk Nanostructured Metals from Twinned Nanowires
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract:
Metals have widespread uses in electronics and infrastructure, and  are the material foundation of modern civilization. A continuous piece of metal is made of densely packed, very fine grains. The size and structure of these grains, and the way they pack together determine the macroscopic properties of the bulk material. Typically, these grains are formed during the growth of the entire bulk material, and can be somewhat restructured during further processing. This project explores a contrasting approach, in which discrete metal nanocrystals are first chemically synthesized to yield well-defined structure, then assembled and densified to yield the final bulk nanostructured metal. This new approach allows for much higher degree of freedom to control the size, structure, and orientation of the metal grains, and can potentially create metal materials with novel properties. 

Technical Abstract:
The new approach for creating bulk nanostructured metals departs fundamentally from the current ones, which are based on extensive plastic deformation of coarse-grained metal, atom-by-atom growth through electroplating or sputtering-based techniques, and consolidation of micron-size metal powders. In the new strategy, well-defined metal grains (i.e., nanowires) are first synthesized "atom-by-atom?" and then assembled to construct the final bulk metal "grain-by-grain". This can effectively decouple the tuning of grain microstructures and grain orientations, leading to new bulk nanostructured metals with previously unattainable microstructures (e.g., grain shape, orientation and nano-twinning) and novel properties. The project addresses a long missing connection between bulk nanostructured alloys (metallurgy-oriented) and colloidal nanomaterials (materials chemistry-oriented). If successful, it will inspire and catalyze a long overdue collaboration between these two independent areas of nanomaterials research. Students trained in the project represent a new breed of material scientists that can connect metallurgy with colloidal nanomaterials, bringing fresh mindsets to both areas.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Metals are a vital material that people interact with every day, be that in the car, the office building they work in, or the espresso maker we use to start our morning. In addition to these seemingly mundane applications, metals are used in cutting edge technologies, space travel, and ever higher reaching skyscrapers. Consequently, materials progress in metals is necessary for pushing the boundaries of human innovation.

This requires that new strategies be developed to take the best or most unique properties of metals, usually found in their nanoscale microstructure, and produce bulk engineering materials. To do this, the project idea—to unite two similar but distant fields of metal nanomaterial research—was put forward. In this, the well-defined nanoscale particles synthesized atom by atom, which typically result in excellent mechanical, electronic, magnetic, and optical properties, are used as building blocks towards making a bulk metal. In this, each individual particle is a grain, and by assembling the grains, a bulk nanostructured metal could be produced, that, if it retains a significant proportion of the starting nanoparticle structure and properties, could lead to a new material.

To pursue this goal, the silver nanowire was chosen as the model system due to its scalable synthesis and unique five-fold twinning microstructure which could lead to improved mechanical properties.  However, preserving this microstructure is notoriously difficult due to the low thermal and pressure stability of silver nanowires. On the other hand, preserving this microstructure is exactly what needs to occur.

To do this, we developed a process to conformally coat silver nanowires with copper that would enable high temperature processing to achieve a cohesive and dense nanostructured metal.  Copper is immiscible with silver, creating a green body that becomes resistant to coarsening and preserved a good proportion of the five-fold twinning boundaries in silver nanowires. This new nanostructured metal showed improved hardness because of the preserved nanowire microstructure.

From this, we have shown that individual metal nanowires can be assembled collectively into a cohesive bulk metal material under proper processing conditions. These conditions are such that a significant proportion of the nanowires are preserved, ensuring a unique microstructure, and, therefore, the potential for unique properties. In addition, this method should provide the basis to explore a wider range of metal nanowires, those which exhibit immiscibility with a second metal element.


Last Modified: 03/24/2021
Modified by: Jiaxing Huang
